entry.content:
West Fork & Moose Peak Daily Fact Sheet 9/21/17

Incident: West Fork Fire Wildfire
Released: 36 min. ago

Fire Information Number: (406) 209-9961 Evacuation Information: (406) 293-6295

Location: West Fork Fire is 7 miles northwest of Libby, MT Size: 20,008

Cause: Lightning Containment: 60% Personnel: 282

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5592/

Location: Moose Peak Fire originated near Moose Peak in Sanders County, MT Size: 13,854

Cause: Lightning Containment: 70% Personnel: 254

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5583/

Visit Lincoln County Webpage www.lincolncountymt.us to sign-up for the County Code Red system.

Public and firefighter safety continues to be our #1 priority. There will not be any further night patrols on either fire.

Weather: Cloudy skies with scattered showers will dominate the general area this week. Today, temperatures are only expected to reach the high 40s with light south winds of 5 mph and minimum relative humidity (RH) around 65%. Snow fall is expected at the 4,000’-4,500’ level with fog in the morning – NOTE: accumulation exists on Mt. Tom and the spot fire area on Gold Hill.

West Fork Fire Yesterday: Fire managers increased containment to 60% that includes the areas of lower Quartz Creek, Bobtail Creek and upper Pipe Creek road near the 17 mile junction. Firefighters patrolled and mopped up on most edges of the fire perimeter. Engines had limited accessibility to fire area due to slick, muddy roads. Back haul of unneeded equipment from the fire-lines is ongoing. Crews were working to remove danger trees weakened by recent fire and weather conditions along public access routes. The residents at 17 mile / Pipe Creek road have had their evacuation status downgraded to pre-evacuation and were allowed to return home. The access to the 17 mile area up Pipe Creek road was opened to residents ONLY with pilot cars escorting them to their properties.

Today’s Planned Actions: With the continued wet weather, firefighters will concentrate on patrolling, holding, and improving all containment lines. Muddy, slick roads may affect firefighter access to all fire areas again. The spot fire near Gold Hill will continue to be monitored. Rehabilitation needs for dozer lines are being identified and completed.

West Fork Fire Evacuations: Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

West Fork Fire Closures: The Kootenai National Forest continues a closure order in effect for the West Fork Fire. The closure order and map are located under the closure tab on the InciWeb page.

_______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Moose Peak Yesterday: Fire managers increased containment to 70% that includes the areas around Miller Lake, Bayhorse Creek, Fishtrap Creek, and McGinnis Meadows. Firefighters concentrated on patrolling, holding, and improving all containment lines. Muddy, slick roads affected firefighter access to all fire areas. Back haul of unneeded equipment from fire-lines is ongoing.

Today’s Planned Actions: With the continued wet weather, firefighters will concentrate on patrolling, holding, and improving all hand and dozer lines established in the East Fisher Creek, McGinnis Creek, and Fishtrap Creek areas. Muddy, slick roads may affect firefighter access to all fire areas again today.

Moose Peak Fire Pre - Evacuations: Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

Moose Peak Fire Closures: The Kootenai National Forest continues a closure order in effect for the Moose Peak Fire area. Sylvan Lake campground has been closed. The closure order and map are located under the closure tab on the InciWeb page.

entry.title: News Release- Kootenai National Forest Fire Update for 09-20-2017
entry.summary: KOOTENAI NATIONAL FOREST FIRE UPDATE FOR SEPTEMBER 20, 2017 LIBBY, Mont. September 20, 2017 – This is the September 20 fire update on the fires that are still burning on the Kootenai National Forest. The Gibralter, Weasel, Caribou, West Fork Moose Peak, and Highway 200 Complex fires are detailed below. Firefighters will continue improving and patrolling containment lines and mop-up any hot spots. The Gibralter Ridge Fire is 12,938 acres and 27 percent contained. The Caribou Fire is 24,753 acres and 50 percent contained. The Weasel Fire is 3,925 acres and no report of containment. The West Fork Fire is 20,008 acres and 55 percent contained. The Moose Peak Fire is 13,854 acres and 67 percent contained. The Highway 200 Complex fires are a combined 47,118 acres and 35 percent contained for the entire complex. The fire acres and containment figures are estimated. With the cooler weather and recent precipitation, minimal fire activity has been reported on these fires. However, the...

entry.content:
Moose Peak / West Fork Fire - 09-20-2017

Incident: Moose Peak Fire Wildfire
Released: 23 min. ago

Related Information

  • West Fork/Moose Peak Fire Fact Sheet - 09/20/2017 (pdf 281 kb)

Fire Information Number: (406) 209-9961 Evacuation Information: (406) 293-6295

Location: West Fork Fire is 7 miles northwest of Libby, MT Size: 20,008

Cause: Lightning Containment: 55% Personnel: 326

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5592/

Location: Moose Peak Fire originated near Moose Peak in Sanders County, MT Size: 13,854

Cause: Lightning Containment: 67% Personnel: 312

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5583/

Visit Lincoln County Webpage www.lincolncountymt.us to sign-up for the County Code Red system.

Public and firefighter safety continues to be our #1 priority. There will not be any further night patrols on either fire.

Weather: Cloudy skies with scattered showers will dominate the general area this week. Today, temperatures are only expected to reach the high 40s with light south winds of 5-10 mph with minimum RH’s around 65%. Rain accumulations on both fire areas have ranged between 1.00 to 1.25 inches over the past 48 hours.

West Fork Fire Yesterday: Fire managers increased containment to 55% that include the areas of lower Quartz Creek, Bobtail Creek and upper Pipe Creek road near 17 mile junction. Firefighters patrolled and mopped up on most edges of the fire perimeter. Engines had limited accessibility to fire area due to slick, muddy roads. Back haul of unneeded equipment from the firelines has begun. An approximate 3 mile section of dozer line and mechanized fuel break has been identified to add to the containment strategy. This section is from the 4696 road near the Bobtail Cutoff road, north to the 4613 road near Noisy Creek. Crews were working to remove danger trees weakened by recent fire and weather conditions along public access routes.

The residents at 17 mile/ Pipe Creek road have had their evacuation status downgraded to pre-evacuation and were allowed to return home. The access to the 17 mile area up Pipe Creek road was opened to residents only with pilot cars.

Today’s Planned Actions: With the continued wet weather, firefighters will concentrate on patrolling, holding, and improving all containment lines. Muddy, slick roads may affect firefighter access to all fire areas again. The spot fire near Gold Hill will continue to be monitored. Rehabilitation needs for dozer lines are being identified and completed.

West Fork Fire Evacuations: Some evacuation orders have been lifted. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

West Fork Fire Closures: The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the West Fork Fire. The closure order and map are located under the closure tab on the Inciweb page.

_______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Moose Peak Yesterday: Fire managers increased containment to 67% that include the areas around Miller Lake, Bayhorse Creek, and McGinnis Meadows. Firefighters concentrated on patrolling, holding, and improving all containment lines. Muddy, slick roads affected firefighter access to all fire areas. Back haul of unneeded equipment has begun.

Today’s Planned Actions: With the continued wet weather, firefighters will concentrate on patrolling, holding, and improving all hand and dozer lines established in the East Fisher Creek, McGinnis Creek and Fishtrap Creek areas. Muddy, slick roads may affect firefighter access to all fire areas again.

Moose Peak Fire Pre - Evacuations: Pre-Evacuation notices have been issued for East Fisher Road, Bayhorse Ranch and McGinnis Meadows. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

Moose Peak Fire Closures: The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the Moose Peak Fire area. Sylvan Lake campground has been closed. The closure order and map are located under the closure tab on the Inciweb page.

entry.content:
Moose Peak and West Fork Fires Daily Fact Sheet 9-19-17

Incident: Moose Peak Fire Wildfire
Released: 37 min. ago

Fire Information Number: (406) 209-9961 Evacuation Information: (406) 293-6295

Location: West Fork Fire is 7 miles northwest of Libby, MT Size: 20,008

Cause: Lightning Containment: 48% Personnel: 326

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5592/

Location: Moose Peak Fire originated near Moose Peak in Sanders County, MT Size: 13,854

Cause: Lightning Containment: 26% Personnel: 158

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5583/

Visit Lincoln County Webpage www.lincolncountymt.us to sign-up for the County Code Red system.

Public and firefighter safety continues to be our #1 priority. Tonight, engine crews will patrol roaded fire perimeters one last shift on both fires.

Weather: Cloudy skies with scattered showers will dominate the general area this week. Today, temperatures are only expected to reach the 50s with light southwest winds of 5 mph with minimum RH’s around 60%. Rain accumulations of 0.25 to 0.50 inches are possible.

West Fork Fire Yesterday: Fire managers increased containment to 48% that include the areas of lower Quartz Creek, Bobtail Creek and upper Pipe Creek road near 17 mile junction. Monday’s rainfall was 0.25 inches. Firefighters patrolled and mopped up on the edges of the burnout areas in the Bull Creek/ Bobtail vicinity and upper Pipe Creek. Engines had limited accessibility to fire area due to slick, muddy roads. Back haul of unneeded equipment from the firelines was begun.

Today’s Planned Actions: With the continued wet weather, firefighters will concentrate on patrolling, holding, and improving all containment lines. Muddy, slick roads may affect firefighter access to all fire areas again. The spot fire near Gold Hill will continue to be monitored. Rehabilitation needs for dozer lines around private property are being identified. Crews are working to remove danger trees weakened by recent fire and weather conditions along public access routes in anticipation of the downgrading of evacuation orders.

West Fork Fire Evacuations: Some evacuation orders have been lifted. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

West Fork Fire Closures: The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the West Fork Fire. The closure order and map are located under the closure tab on the Inciweb page.

_______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Moose Peak Yesterday: Fire managers increased containment to 26% that include the areas around Miller Lake, Bayhorse Creek, and McGinnis Meadows. Monday’s rainfall was 0.50 inches. Firefighters concentrated on patrolling, holding, and improving all containment lines. Muddy, slick roads affected firefighter access to all fire areas. Back haul of unneeded equipment was begun.

Today’s Planned Actions: With the continued wet weather, firefighters will concentrate on patrolling, holding, and improving all hand and dozer lines established in the East Fisher Creek, McGinnis Creek and Fishtrap Creek areas. Muddy, slick roads may affect firefighter access to all fire areas again.

Moose Peak Fire Pre - Evacuations: Pre-Evacuation notices have been issued for East Fisher Road, Bayhorse Ranch and McGinnis Meadows. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

Moose Peak Fire Closures: The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the Moose Peak Fire area. Sylvan Lake campground has been closed. The closure order and map are located under the closure tab on the Inciweb page.

entry.content:
Daily Update 9/18 Highway 200 Complex Fires

Incident: Highway 200 Complex Wildfire
Released: 27 min. ago

Approximate Size (acres/%containment):
Sheep Gap –24,816/40
Deep & Miller Creek –16,327/0

Cub Creek –5,823/11
Readers – 152/95
TOTAL – 47,118/18

Total personnel: 538

Location: The Highway 200 Complex fires are located in Sanders County, MT near the towns of Thompson Falls and Plains. The Sheep Gap fire is approximately 2 miles west of Plains. The remaining complex fires are located 8 miles north and west of Thompson Falls.

Evacuations and Closures: The Sanders County Sheriff's Office has lifted the evacuation notice for Swamp Creek Road from Four Corners to the intersection of the East and West fork of Swamp Creek. Pre-evacuation warnings are in place on Blackjack Rd. from Four Corners to where it intersects River Rd West and Swamp Creek Road from Four Corners to the intersection of the East and West fork of Swamp Creek. Other areas under pre-evacuation remain so. Members of the Montana Army National Guard are assisting with road closures, pre-evacuations, and any other assistance that may be needed. The Forest Service, Sanders County, and DNRC have placed area closures around the fires as they are integral to public safety and safe fire operations. Although areas around the fires have been closed, the majority of lands in the area are still open for all types of activities.

Fire Update: Cooler and moister weather conditions have caused the fires to be less active with little growth through the weekend. Some edges of the fires were still active, but overall fire activity is limited to within the lines. These weather conditions are allowing firefighters to suppress the fire directly by treating burning fuels on the perimeter of the fire. Aerial water drops by helicopters were done on areas with more active fire.

Weather and Fire Behavior: Monday will be cloudy as a cold front system will bring better chances of a steady rain. Wetting rain and cold temperatures will further limit fire activity.

Fire Details:

Sheep Gap – Crews continued constructing a line above Mountain Rd residences and to the east near the fire’s edge. They will continue this operation on Monday to protect the homes below and contain spread to the east. On the northwest flank above Eddy Creek the line was improved and will be held using water drops if needed. On the south side of the fire, crews will scout for opportunities for line construction and will patrol and improve existing line. The fire remained active late in the evening and crews remained alert to keep the fire out of the structures.

Deep Creek/Miller Creek – Helicopters dropped water on the fire around Benson Peak to slow the fire’s growth as it backed downslope. Crews held existing lines to keep the fire west of Graves Creek, and east of Deep Creek. Crews will work along the southwest face of the fire and go direct where possible to bring the fire down to an old road system above the homes. Operations will continue to hold the fire between Graves and Deep Creeks. The northeast flank will be scouted to identify possible locations for line construction. There was a slop over found across Graves Creek by crews and engines that has been contained.

Cub Creek – Crews finished removing snags along a control line above Cub Creek. Lines were constructed along existing roads above Haines Gulch. They will continue this work today to prevent further fire spread down Little Beaver Creek. Firefighters will establish control line, hold previously created black line, and patrol the roads around the southwest side of the fire.

Reader Fires – There was no change in activity on these fires. An engine crew will continue to monitor these fires.

entry.title: Evacuation Lifted and Forest Closure Notices
entry.summary: According to the Sanders County Sheriff's Office, all evacuation notices for the Highway 200 Complex fires have been lifted. All areas in the evacuation and pre-evacuation area are all now considered under pre-evacuation notice until otherwise notified by the sheriff's office. Although the weather has turned considerably colder and wetter, there are still many areas with closure orders in place. Firefighters are still working to control these fires that have uncontrolled firelines and several other hazards. To protect the safety of firefighters and the general public, please adhere to these closure orders until further notice. Maps and orders can be found on the closures tab. Many other areas are open for public recreation. Contact your local Forest Service office for information regarding areas open for public

entry.content:
Moose Peak and West Fork Fires Daily Fact Sheet 9-18-17

Incident: Moose Peak Fire Wildfire
Released: 17 min. ago

Fire Information Number: (406) 209-9961 Evacuation Information: (406) 293-6295

Location: West Fork Fire is 7 miles northwest of Libby, MT Size: 19,497

Cause: Lightning Containment: 33% Personnel: 396

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5592/

Location: Moose Peak Fire originated near Moose Peak in Sanders County, MT Size: 12,624

Cause: Lightning Containment: 11% Personnel: 158

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5583/

Visit Lincoln County Webpage www.lincolncountymt.us to sign-up for the County Code Red system.

Community Meeting – West Fork Fire – Libby Christian Church – Monday, September 18th, 6 pm

Air support is available on both fires to assist suppression efforts as conditions allow. Structure assessment and protection measures have been implemented throughout both fire areas. Engine crews have been patrolling roaded fire perimeters overnight on both fires. Burnout operations are designed to create a low intensity, backing fire toward a containment point that fire managers can most safely and efficiently contain an active fire.

Weather: Cloudy skies with scattered showers will dominate the general area this week. Today, temperatures are only expected to reach the mid-50s with southwest winds 10-20 mph with minimum RH’s around 45%. Rain accumulations of 0.25 to 0.50 inches are possible.

West Fork Fire Yesterday: Fire managers increased containment to 33% that include areas of lower Quartz Creek and Bobtail Creek. Hotshot crews have completed hand burnout on the northeast flank east of Mt. Tom with a backing fire toward the Pipe Creek road. Firefighters patrolled and mopped up on the edges of the burnout in the Bull Creek/ Bobtail vicinity. All needed fuel break construction has been completed along Pipe Creek road.

Today’s Planned Actions: With the approaching wet weather, firefighters will concentrate on patrolling, holding, and improving all containment lines. The spot fire near Gold Hill will be monitored. Some rehabilitation of dozer lines around private property has started.

West Fork Fire Evacuations: Some evacuation orders have been lifted. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

West Fork Fire Closures: The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the West Fork Fire. The closure order and map are located under the closure tab on the Inciweb page.

_______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Moose Peak Yesterday: Fire managers established containment of 11% that includes the northwest flank area around Miller Lake. Hotshot crews patrolled hand and dozer lines in East Fisher Creek on the north flank. The large aerial burnout operation on the northeast flank in the vicinity of McGinnis Meadows was patrolled and minor mop-up work along the edges was done A swing shift detected a spot fire about 2 acres in size and had it contained by 3 a.m. this morning. Mechanical fuel breaks were also extended southeast into the Fishtrap drainage.

Today’s Planned Actions: With the approaching wet weather, firefighters will further extend or hold and improve all hand and dozer lines and mechanized fuel breaks in the East Fisher Creek, McGinnis Creek and Fishtrap Creek areas. Saturday’s burnout will continue to be patrolled for containment issues.

The Deep Creek Fire located a few miles to the southwest of the Moose Peak Fire is being monitored by aerial resources.

Moose Peak Fire Pre - Evacuations: Pre-Evacuation notices have been issued for East Fisher Road, Bayhorse Ranch and McGinnis Meadows. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

Moose Peak Fire Closures: The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the Moose Peak Fire area. Sylvan Lake campground has been closed. The closure order and map are located under the closure tab on the Inciweb Page.

entry.content:
Weasel Fire Update 09.17.2017

Incident: Weasel Wildfire
Released: 19 min. ago

Fire Information Line: 406-272-2082 · Estimated acres – No IR

Location: Caribou Fire located 21 miles northwest of Eureka, MT Current Size: 24,753 Total Acres

Cause: Lightning Containment: 50% Personnel: 310 United States: 21,992 Canada: 2,761

Email: CaribouFire2017@gmail.com Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5539/

Location: Gibralter Ridge Fire located seven miles east of Eureka, MT Current Size: 12,938 Acres

Cause: Lightning Containment: 37% Personnel: 47

Email: GibralterRidgeFire2017@gmail.com Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5474/

Location: Weasel Fire located 17 miles northeast of Eureka, MT Current Size: ·3,925 Acres

Cause: Lightning Containment: 0% Personnel: 0

Email: GibralterRidgeFire2017@gmail.com Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5605/

Changing Weather, Suppression Repair Continues

Caribou Fire: On the east and southeast edges of the fire near West Kootenai, fire crews are beginning to repair firelines, starting with the contingency line west of Tooley Lake. Isolated burning is occurring in heavy continuous fuels including some old Lodgepole stands in the Lime Creek area. In the southwest area of the fire, firefighters completed chipping and are hauling slash along the Road 999. Today’s unsettled weather will bring warm westerly flow of winds in advance of Monday’s cold front.

Caribou Evacuations: None.

Caribou Fire Closures: A Closure Order remains in place for the Caribou Fire. Closure Orders and maps under the “Closures” tab on Inciweb.

Gibralter Ridge Fire: Fire activity in the Whale Creek drainage was minimal, but with some active fire on the west side of Williams Creek drainage. Firefighters are continuing the work of removing fuels along Grave Creek Road, by chipping slash created from brush removal operations. Crews continue to patrol the fire area to mop-up hot spots.

Gibralter Ridge Evacuations: None.

Gibralter Ridge Closures: Grave Creek Road and the Ten Lakes Recreation area are closed above the Grave Creek/Foothills Road junction. Closure Orders and maps under the “Closures” tab on Inciweb.

Weasel Fire: Yesterday, some isolated torching occurred along Tuchuck Mountain. No private property or structures are threatened.

Weather: Today’s unsettled weather will bring warm strong westerly winds at 15 mph with gust to 25 mph on ridgetops. Temperatures will be in the high 60s with increase smoke in the morning hours.

Resources Threatened: Private property, structures, historic resources, recreational resources, timber, terrestrial and aquatic habitats.

Fire Restrictions: Lincoln County and the Kootenai National Forest are in Stage II Fire Restrictions due to Extreme Fire Danger. For information on fire restrictions, please visit firerestrictions.us

Community Meeting – West Fork Fire – Libby Christian Church – Monday, September 18th, 6 pm

Air support is available on both fires to assist suppression efforts as conditions allow. Structure assessment and protection measures have been implemented throughout both fires. Engine crews have been patrolling roaded fire perimeters overnight on both fires. The burnout operation is designed to create a low intensity, backing fire toward a containment point that fire managers can most safely and efficiently contain an active fire. Smoke in our area is mostly due to our ongoing burnout operations needed to further secure all containment perimeters.

Weather: Temperatures are expected to reach the upper 60s with southwest winds 5-15 mph on Sunday as warm and dry conditions rebuild with RH’s down to 20%. Skies will be mostly clear after the morning inversion lifts. Low temperatures are expected to be freezing in the valley bottoms.

West Fork Fire Yesterday: Fire managers increased containment to 29% that include areas of lower Quartz Creek and Bobtail Creek. Hotshot crews have completed the hand burnout on the north flank that is tied into the aerial ignition operation east of Mt. Tom toward the Pipe Creek road on the northeast flank. Firefighters also completed a rather large hand burnout in the Bull Creek vicinity that has tied in with mechanical fuel break construction progressing westerly from Pipe Creek road and a dozer line into Bobtail Creek.

Today’s Planned Actions: The aerial ignition operation east of Mt. Tom on the northeast flank will progress toward the Pipe Creek road. Firefighters will patrol yesterday’s burnout in Bull Creek for any containment issues. Additional burnout operations in the Bull Creek vicinity may progress as conditions and need occur. Firefighters will further the mechanized fuel break construction along Pipe Creek Road area to strengthen containment perimeters. The spot fire near Gold Hill will to be monitored.

West Fork Fire Evacuations: Some evacuation orders have been lifted. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

West Fork Fire Closures: The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the West Fork Fire. The closure order and map are located under the closure tab on the Inciweb page.

_______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Moose Peak Yesterday: Hotshot crews extended direct hand lines that tie into dozer lines in East Fisher Creek on the north flank. A rather large aerial burnout operation was conducted on the northeast flank in the vicinity of McGinnis Meadows to reinforce our mechanical fuel break lines. Mechanical fuel breaks were also extended southeast into the Fishtrap drainage.

Today’s Planned Actions: Firefighters will further extend or hold and improve all hand and dozer lines and mechanized fuel breaks in the East Fisher Creek, McGinnis Creek and Fishtrap Creek areas. Yesterday’s burnout will be patrolled for containment issues.

The Deep Creek Fire located a few miles to the southwest of the Moose Peak Fire is being monitored by aerial resources.

Moose Peak Fire Pre - Evacuations: Pre-Evacuation notices have been issued for East Fisher Road, Bayhorse Ranch and McGinnis Meadows. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

entry.summary: Highway 200 Complex Northern Rockies Type II Incident Management Team Irv Leach Incident Commander Announcement September 17, 2017 Fireline Explosives Operation Firecrews are planning to use fireline explosives this afternoon to help build a small piece of line on part of the eastern side of the Sheep Gap fire to tie in with existing dozer line. This line construction tool is being used because of the brushy fuel type in the area intermixed with scree. Using hand crews to build this line would take up to 2 days to accomplish. This would delay the production of the containment line, as well as expose firefighters to undue risk. Fireline explosives are used by trained crews that install specially developed coils containing explosive gel, known as detonation cord. This operation will take a few hours to install. When the explosives are detonated, area residents may hear the explosion. When complete, hand crews will...
entry.content:
Fireline Explosive Announcement September 17

Incident: Highway 200 Complex Wildfire
Released: 28 min. ago

Highway 200 Complex

Northern Rockies Type II Incident Management Team

Irv Leach Incident Commander

Announcement

September 17, 2017

Fireline Explosives Operation

Firecrews are planning to use fireline explosives this afternoon to help build a small piece of line on part of the eastern side of the Sheep Gap fire to tie in with existing dozer line. This line construction tool is being used because of the brushy fuel type in the area intermixed with scree. Using hand crews to build this line would take up to 2 days to accomplish. This would delay the production of the containment line, as well as expose firefighters to undue risk. Fireline explosives are used by trained crews that install specially developed coils containing explosive gel, known as detonation cord. This operation will take a few hours to install. When the explosives are detonated, area residents may hear the explosion. When complete, hand crews will patrol the line and make sure it is clear of brush and slash.

entry.content:
Highway 200 Complex Daily Update, September 16, 8 a.m.

Incident: Highway 200 Complex Wildfire
Released: 3 hrs. ago

Approximate Size (acres/%containment):
Sheep Gap –24,816 acres/40%
Deep & Miller Creek –15,894 acres/0%

Cub Creek –5,690 acres/11%
Readers – 152 acres/95%
TOTAL – 46,552 acres/10%

Total personnel: 336

Location: The Highway 200 Complex fires are located in Sanders County, MT near the towns of Thompson Falls and Plains. The Sheep Gap fire is approximately 2 miles west of Plains. The remaining complex fires are located 8 miles north and west of Thompson Falls.

Evacuations and Closures: The Sanders County Sheriff's Office has evacuated Swamp Creek Road from Four Corners to the intersection of the East and West fork of Swamp Creek. Pre-evacuations were completed on Blackjack Rd. from Four Corners to where it intersects River Rd West. Additional areas under evacuation orders include Glades Ranch, Cat Track Lane to Mountain subdivision and the residences between that are south of Blackjack Road, and Foothill Lane. These areas have been closed by the Sheriff’s office. Members of the Montana Army National Guard are assisting with road closures, pre-evacuations, evacuations, and any other assistance that may be needed. The Forest Service has also placed area closure orders around the fires as they are integral to public safety and safe fire operations. Although areas around the fires have been closed, the majority of lands in the area are still open for all types of activities.

Fire Update: Fire activity was limited Friday with the cooler, moister conditions. There was no significant fire growth and activity was mainly limited to spread on the ground with a small amount of single tree torching. The fires were observed and mapped from the air to provide better information on the perimeter. Acres reported reflect this mapping effort. Previous acres were based on infrared flights that were obscured by cloud cover. The increase in acres is a result of this improved mapping, not because of fire growth today. Helicopters dropped about 120 buckets of water on the fires to calm fire spread. More crews and equipment are arriving to the fire as other fires release these resources because of improving conditions. Even with a quieter fire and improved weather conditions, Incident Commander Irv Leach told the crews at briefing “We aren’t letting our guard down. There is still plenty of work to do to protect the high values at risk. We’re in this for the long haul.”

Weather and Fire Behavior: Part of Sheep Gap received rain and snow at the highest elevation; the remainder and the other fires were dry. The recent moist system will leave the area and be replaced by a high pressure system. Temperatures and humidity will rebound with slight warming and drying through the weekend. Winds will be light from the west. Another storm system is expected to arrive on Monday with another chance for precipitation. Fire behavior will increase Saturday as fuels warm and dry, but it is not expected to be as active as earlier in the week. The northeast part of Deep-Miller fire near Lone Tree Peak may see the greatest potential for active fire growth as it moves downslope.

Fire Details:

Sheep Gap – A dozer line from the existing line on the northeast flank was constructed above residences. Opportunities for additional line were scouted in advance of this line. On the northwest flank above Eddy Creek the line was improved above the houses. Line construction on the southeast side will continue Saturday with the plan to extend around the eastern flank and scout around the fire for additional line opportunities. Line on the northwest flank will be held and improved.

Deep Creek/Miller Creek – Helicopters dropped water on the fire above houses to slow the fire’s growth as it backed downslope. There had been considerable fire growth prior to the arrival of the weather system on the northeast flank. Much of this was spotty with unburned fuels scattered in the perimeter. This area was scouted in advance for placement of possible line construction. On Saturday crews will hold existing lines and fire movement will be slowed as it continues to back downslope.

Cub Creek – Line construction occurred above Little Beaver Creek on the fire’s south side. On the north side, the fire was kept in check with helicopter water drops above Haines Gulch. Saturday crews will continue to hold existing lines and minimize fire movement with helicopters.

Reader Fires – There was no change in activity on these fires.

Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5583/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Highway200Complex

Email: hwy200complex@gmail.com

Phone: (406) 219-1960

entry.content:
Moose Peak and West Fork Fires Daily Fact Sheet 9-16-17

Incident: Moose Peak Fire Wildfire
Released: 4 hrs. ago

Fire Information Number: (406) 209-9961 Evacuation Information: (406) 293-6295

Location: West Fork Fire is 7 miles northwest of Libby, MT Size: 17,265

Cause: Lightning Containment: 22% Personnel: 256

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5592/

Location: Moose Peak Fire originated near Moose Peak in Sanders County, MT Size: 11,737

Cause: Lightning Containment: 0% Personnel: 158

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5583/

Visit Lincoln County Webpage www.lincolncountymt.us to sign-up for the County Code Red system.

Weather: Temperatures are expected to reach the mid 60s with light easterly winds of 5-10 mph on Saturday and Sunday as warm and dry conditions rebuild. Skies will be mostly clear after the morning inversion lifts. Low temperatures will be near freezing in the valley bottoms.

West Fork Fire Yesterday: Fire managers increased containment to 22% that include areas of lower Quartz Creek and Bobtail Creek. Hotshot crews continued with burnout operations on the north flank connecting with roads and dozer lines. Firefighters began an aerial ignition operation east of Mt Tom to the Pipe Creek road. Firefighters also completed some hand burnout operations in the Bull Creek vicinity that tied in with mechanical fuel break construction progressing westerly from Pipe Creek road along Rd. 4614. Helicopters made water bucket drops on the spot fire near Gold Hill and hot spots in Quartz Creek. Engine crews patrolled fire perimeter to monitor fire conditions overnight.

Today’s Planned Actions: Hotshot crews will work to progress the burnout operation down to the Pipe Creek road on the north flank. The spot fire near Gold Hill will to be monitored. The aerial ignition operation east of Mt Tom will progress a low intensity, backing fire toward Pipe Creek road. Air operations are available as conditions allow in supporting suppression efforts. Structure assessment and protection measures will be implemented throughout the fire area. Firefighters will further the mechanized fuel break construction along Pipe Creek Road area to strengthen containment perimeters.

West Fork Fire Evacuations: Some evacuation orders have been lifted. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

West Fork Fire Closures: The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the West Fork Fire. The closure order and map are located under the closure tab on the Inciweb page.

Moose Peak Yesterday: The cooler temperatures and higher humidity resulted in minimal fire activity in the East Fisher Creek area to the north and Fishtrap Creek on the east. Hotshot crews held and improved firelines that tie into dozer lines. Firefighters prioritized needed structure assessments and implemented protection measures.

Today’s Planned Actions: Firefighters will further construct dozer lines and mechanized fuel breaks northwest of Miller Lake in the East Fisher Creek area and on the northeast flank in the McGinnis Creek area. Structure assessment and protection will continue throughout the fire area. Air operations are available as conditions allow supporting suppression efforts. The Deep Creek Fire located a few miles to the south east of the Moose Peak Fire is being monitored by aerial resources.

Moose Peak Fire Pre - Evacuations: Pre-Evacuation notices have been issued for East Fisher Road, Bayhorse Ranch and McGinnis Meadows. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

Moose Peak Fire Closures: The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the Moose Peak Fire area. Sylvan Lake campground has been closed. The closure order and map are located under the closure tab on the Inciweb Page.

entry.content:
Weasel Fire Update 09-16-2017

Incident: Weasel Wildfire
Released: 5 hrs. ago

Related Information

  • Weasel Fire Update 09-16-2017 (pdf 174 kb)

Fire Information Line: 406-272-2082

Location: Caribou Fire located 21 miles northwest of Eureka, MT Current Size: 24,206 Total Acres
Cause: Lightning Containment: 50% Personnel: 328 United States: 21,534 Canada: 2,672
Email: CaribouFire2017@gmail.com Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5539/

Location: Gibralter Ridge Fire located seven miles east of Eureka, MT Current Size: 12,725 Acres
Cause: Lightning Containment: 27% Personnel: 48
Email: GibralterRidgeFire2017@gmail.com Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5474/

Location: Weasel Fire located 17 miles northeast of Eureka, MT Current Size: 3,925 Acres
Cause: Lightning Containment: 0% Personnel: 0
Email: GibralterRidgeFire2017@gmail.com Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5605/

As Mop-Up Progresses, Suppression Repair Begins

Caribou Fire: Mop-up work is complete on the east and southeast edges of the fire near West Kootenai. In those areas, fire crews are beginning to repair firelines, starting with the contingency line west of Tooley Lake. In the southwest area of the fire, firefighters are continuing to chip slash along the Yaak River Road (Forest Road 92), and are controlling the fire as it slowly reaches that prepared fireline. Last night, Incident Commander Shawn Pearson and his staff presented a detailed briefing to 75 residents at the West Kootenai Store, and answered questions.
Caribou Evacuations: None.
Caribou Fire Closures: A Closure Order remains in place for the Caribou Fire. Closure Orders and maps under the “Closures” tab on Inciweb.

Gibralter Ridge Fire: The fire’s movement down the Whale Creek drainage was minimal, due to yesterday’s cold, moist weather. Firefighters are continuing the work of removing fuels along Grave Creek Road, by chipping slash created from brush removal operations. Crews continue to patrol the fire area to mop-up hot spots.
Gibralter Ridge Evacuations: None.
Gibralter Ridge Closures: Grave Creek Road and the Ten Lakes Recreation area are closed above the Grave Creek/Foothills Road junction. Closure Orders and maps under the “Closures” tab on Inciweb.

Weasel Fire: Yesterday, aerial observers reported that the fire had moved very little along Tuchuck Mountain due to yesterday’s cool weather. No private property or structures are threatened.

Weather: Today’s weather will remain favorable to fire control, with temperatures below 60 degrees and relative humidity 36-45%. Winds will be light and variable throughout the day.

Resources Threatened: Private property, structures, historic resources, recreational resources, timber, terrestrial and aquatic habitats.

Fire Restrictions: Lincoln County and the Kootenai National Forest are in Stage II Fire Restrictions due to Extreme Fire Danger. For information on fire restrictions, please visit firerestrictions.us

Cooler weather is expected to moderate fire activity again today with slightly warmer and drier conditions expected for the weekend. Rain is in the forecast for early next week. ...
entry.content:
Moose Peak and West Fork Fires Daily Fact Sheet 9-15-17

Incident: Moose Peak Fire Wildfire
Released: 1 day ago

Fire Information Number: (406) 209-9961 Evacuation Information: (406) 293-6295

Location: West Fork Fire is 7 miles northwest of Libby, MT Size: 16,940

Cause: Lightning Containment: 19% Personnel: 262

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5592/

Location: Moose Peak Fire originated near Moose Peak in Sanders County, MT Size: 11,587

Cause: Lightning Containment: 0% Personnel: 144

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5583/

Visit Lincoln County Webpage www.lincolncountymt.us to sign-up for the County Code Red system.

Weather: Temperatures are expected to be in the upper 50s with mostly clear skies after the morning inversion lifts. Winds will be light and from the east. Cooler weather is expected to moderate fire activity again today with slightly warmer and drier conditions expected for the weekend. Rain is in the forecast for early next week.

West Fork Fire Yesterday: Firefighters increased containment to 19% on the lower Quartz Creek and Bobtail Creek Roads. Helicopters made drops on the spot fire near Gold Hill. Hotshot crews completed burnout on the north flank of the fire to secure firelines. Crews worked to improve dozer lines on the south and west sides of the fire near Quartz Creek Rd. Engine crews patrolled to monitor fire conditions overnight.

Today’s Planned Actions: Crews will be working to build and improve fireline on the north flank of the fire, and will continue to monitor the spot fire near Gold Hill. A potential aerial ignition is being considered east of Mt Tom to the Pipe Creek Road. Air operations will continue as conditions allow to support suppression efforts. Structure assessment and protection will continue throughout the fire area. Crews will continue to use mechanized fuel break construction along Pipe Creek Road area to improve fire line perimeter.

West Fork Fire Evacuations: Some evacuation orders have been lifted. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

West Fork Fire Closures: The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the West Fork Fire. The closure order and map are located under the closure tab on the Inciweb Page.

Moose Peak Yesterday: Despite cooler temperatures and higher humidity the fire continued to be moderately active in the Fisher Creek area to the north and Fishtrap Creek on the east. Hotshot crews continued to improve firelines and Super Scooper aircraft made drops in these areas to support fire suppression. Firefighters continued to make structure assessments and are implementing protection measures. The Deep Creek Fire located a few miles to the south east of the Moose Peak Fire is being monitored by aerial resources.

Today’s Planned Actions: Firefighters will continue to construct dozer lines and mechanized fuel breaks northwest of Miller Lake in the East Fisher Creek area and on the east flank in the Fishtrap Creek area. Structure assessment and protection will continue throughout the fire area. Air operations will continue as conditions allow supporting suppression efforts.

Moose Peak Fire Pre - Evacuations: Pre-Evacuation notices have been issued for East Fisher Road, Bayhorse Ranch and McGinnis Meadows. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

Moose Peak Fire Closures: Sylvan Lake campground has been closed. The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the Moose Peak Fire. The closure order and map are located under the closure tab on the Inciweb Page.

###

Location: The Highway 200 Complex fires are located in Sanders County, MT near the towns of Thompson Falls and Plains. The Sheep Gap fire is approximately 2 miles west of Plains. The remaining complex fires are located 8 miles north and west of Thompson Falls.

Evacuations and Closures: The Sanders County Sheriff's Office conducted evacuations on Swamp Creek Road from Four Corners to the intersection of the East and West fork of Swamp Creek. Pre-evacuations were completed from Four Corners to 132 Blackjack Rd. and from 132 Blackjack Rd. to where it intersects River Rd West. Additional areas under evacuation orders include Glades Ranch, Cat Track Lane to Mountain subdivision and the residences between south of Blackjack Road, and Foothill Lane. These areas have been closed by the Sheriff’s office. Members of the Montana Army National Guard are assisting with road closures, pre-evacuations, evacuations, and any other assistance that may be needed. The Forest Service has also placed area closure orders around the fires as they are integral to safe fire operations. Visit the Inciweb Closures tab for details and map of the closures.

Fire Update: Fire behavior calmed today with the arrival of the predicted storm system. Although no rain was seen on the fire areas, cloud cover, cooler temperatures, and higher humidity significantly decreased fire activity. Firefighters were able to keep holding the fires where safe to do so and scout for opportunities to corral the latest fire spread. Crews also continue to identify and protect structures and values at risk. As other fires in Montana receive wetting rain and are brought under better control, released resources are being procured for use amongst the ongoing fires.

Weather and Fire Behavior: As the low pressure system moves through the area, temperatures are predicted to remain cooler today (upper 50s to lower 60s) with a corresponding rise in humidity. The weekend forecast calls for a slight warming trend but is not expected to be as unseasonably warm and dry as it has been. There is chance for frost overnight with slight potentials for rain. Fire behavior will diminish with the weather but the severity of dry vegetation conditions and prevalent topography are likely to continue fire spread.


Fire Details

Sheep Gap – Dozers, engines, and handcrews were used yesterday to corral the large fire expansion on the southeast edge of this fire. A line was scouted and a plan made to continue these efforts today. Firefighters and heavy equipment will continue to provide structure protection along the east flank of the fire. They will also patrol for, and suppress, any spot fires that resulted from the increased fire activity. Pre-evacuation and evacuation orders are in place as described above.

Deep Creek/Miller Creek – Fire spread is expected to slow today. Firefighters are working to hold the fire from crossing Deep Creek and preventing growth to the north. Sprinkler systems were being constructed to protect wooden bridges in the area. A pre-evacuation order is still in effect east of the Clark Fork River in the Blue Slide Area.

Cub Creek – Limited surface fire will support firefighters in the implementation of ongoing tactics. Fire will move downslope into Emma and Clear Creek and Little Beaver drainage. Firefighters will continue to control and hold the fire at roads 2262, 301 and Clear Creek. Pre-Evacuation orders are in effect for an area west of Highway 200 from White Pine Creek to Cherry Creek.

Reader Fires – The Reader 1 and Reader 2 fires continue to hold at existing fire lines. Fire activity will be minimal creeping and smoldering. Engines will continue to patrol and mop-up as needed to keep lines secure.

Fire Information Line: 406-272-2082 · Estimated acres, no infrared

Location: Caribou Fire located 21 miles northwest of Eureka, MT Current Size: ·24,177 Total Acres

Cause: Lightning Containment: 50%· Personnel: 332 United States: ·21,527 Canada: ·2,650

Email: CaribouFire2017@gmail.com Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5539/

Location: Gibralter Ridge Fire located seven miles east of Eureka, MT Current Size: ·12,725 Acres

Cause: Lightning Containment: 27% Personnel: 48

Email: GibralterRidgeFire2017@gmail.com Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5474/

Location: Weasel Fire located 17 miles northeast of Eureka, MT Current Size: ·3,925 Acres

Cause: Lightning Containment: 0% Personnel: 0

Colder Temperatures Friday, Minimal Fire Activity

Caribou Fire: Mop-up continues along the east and southeast side of the fire. Firefighters and equipment operators completed fireline construction and are mopping up along the north side of Marias Mountain. Fireline construction is nearing completion on the southwest side of the fire. Log hauling operations were completed in the Blacktail Creek area. Chipping and slash cleanup will continue along the Yaak River Road (Forest Road 92).

Caribou Evacuations: The Pre-Evacuation Warning has been lifted by the Lincoln County Sheriff for West Kootenai North and South, Spring Creek, Dodge Creek, and Basin Creek effective at 9 am today.

Caribou Fire Closures: A Closure Order remains in place for the Caribou Fire. Closure Orders and maps under the “Closures” tab on Inciweb.

Public Meeting: A public meeting will be held on Friday, 9/15 at the West Kootenai Store from 7 pm to 8 pm.


Gibralter Ridge Fire: Slash removal from brushing operations and chipping will continue along the Grave Creek Road. Crews will remain in the area to patrol and mop-up hot spots. The fire made minimal movement down the Whale Creek drainage on the Flathead National Forest (FNF). FNF fire crews have wrapped the Ninko cabin, cleared out timber around the cabin and continue to implement structure protection operations.

Gibralter Ridge Evacuations: The Pre-Evacuation Warning has been lifted by the Lincoln County for the Sherman Creek, Griffith Creek, Therriault Pass Road, Stevens Creek, Glen Lake and Sinclair Creek (south/east of West Road) areas, effective at 9 am today.

Gibralter Ridge Closures: Grave Creek Road and the Ten Lakes Recreation area are closed above the Grave Creek/Foothills Road junction. Closure Orders and maps under the “Closures” tab on Inciweb.

Weasel Fire: The fire has been slowly progressing along the northwest flank of Tuchuck Mountain. Subalpine Fir stands and heavy brush are contributing to the fire spread flanking both sides of Weasel Lake. The Weasel Cabin and dock are wrapped with fire resistant material. No private property or structures are threatened.

Weather: Cooler temperatures, higher relative humidity and northeast winds are in the forecast today. Cooler air will decrease temperatures to the 50s in the mountains and relative humidity will increase to 35-45%. Winds will be 10-15 mph on the ridgetops and 5-10 mph on the slope and valley bottom.

Resources Threatened: Private property, structures, historic resources, recreational resources, timber, terrestrial and aquatic habitats.

Fire Restrictions: Lincoln County and the Kootenai National Forest are in Stage II Fire Restrictions due to Extreme Fire Danger. For information on fire restrictions, please visit firerestrictions.us

entry.content:
Moose Peak and West Fork Fires Daily Fact Sheet 9-13-17

Incident: Moose Peak Fire Wildfire
Released: 17 min. ago

Fire Information Number: (406) 209-9961 Evacuation Information: (406) 293-6295

Location: West Fork Fire is 7 miles northwest of Libby, MT Size: 14,827

Cause: Lightning Containment: 0% Personnel: 238

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5592/

Location: Moose Peak Fire originated near Moose Peak in Sanders County, MT Size: 8,830

Cause: Lightning Containment: 0% Personnel: 73

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5583/

Visit Lincoln County Webpage www.lincolncountymt.us to sign-up for the County Code Red notification system.

Weather: Partly to mostly cloudy with haze today. Maximum temperatures should reach 77 and humidity 20-25%. West winds will be 10-20 mph, then switch to the north later in the day and continue through the night. A slight chance of rain is forecasted for Thursday with a better possibility of wetting rain overnight into Friday morning. The higher humidity and cooler temperatures should help to moderate fire activity towards the end of the week.

West Fork Fire Yesterday: As expected, yesterday was an active burning day and additional air resources were ordered but not able to be utilized until late afternoon because of heavy smoke over the fire. Burnout operations and helicopters dropping water near structures helped hold the fire along the Quartz Creek Road, and fixed wing aircraft dropped water on the far northeast side near Mount Tom. The fire backed down towards Pipe Creek close to 417 Rd north of Mt. Tom and continued backing downslope to the Quartz Creek Road on the west side. The spotfire located several miles northeast of the West Fork Fire grew to 20 acres and continues to be monitored from the air.

Today’s Planned Actions: Crews will continue to patrol and hold the fire to the east along logging roads connecting Bobtail Ridge and the Pipe Creek Road, and north on Pipe Creek Road. Additional engines and personnel were added for structure protection in the Pipe Creek area. Two additional hotshot crews are expected to arrive today to assist in constructing firelines and conducting burnout operations. Similar to yesterday, smoke over the fire area may ground aircraft until later in the day.

West Fork Fire Evacuations: Some evacuation orders have been lifted. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

West Fork Fire Closures: The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the West Fork Fire. The map and order is located under the closure tab on the Inciweb Page.

Moose Peak Yesterday: Firefighters continued to prep the 7150 Road above Miller Lake. Air over the Moose Peak fire was clearer than the West Fork so, although several spot fires were actively burning, helicopters were able to perform bucket drops in the area to control the lines. The Miller Creek Fire is located 2 to 3 miles south of the Moose Peak Fire and burning to the north towards the Moose Creek Fire. It is part of the Highway 200 Complex on the Lolo National Forest and is being closely monitored by air as visibility allows. Smoke from both fires was very visible yesterday afternoon as the fires burned actively.

Today’s Planned Actions: Structure protection and burnout operations will continue, expecting to hold the fire and attempt to prevent spread. With the changing weather conditions, crews will be able to attempt minimal movement of the fires.

Moose Peak Fire Pre - Evacuations: Evacuation notices have been issued for East Fisher Rd and Bayhorse Ranch. Pre-Evacuation notices have been issued for McGinnis Meadows. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

Moose Peak Fire Closures: Sylvan Lake campground has been closed as well as. The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the Moose Peak Fire. The map and order is located under the closure tab on the Inciweb Page.

Cause: Lightning Containment: 30% Personnel: 395 United States: ·20,610 Canada: ·2,577

Email: CaribouFire2017@gmail.com Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5539/

Cause: Lightning Containment: 27% Personnel: 41

Email: GibralterRidgeFire2017@gmail.com Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5474/

Location: Weasel Fire located 17 miles northeast of Eureka, MT Current Size: ·869 Acres

Cause: Lightning Containment: 0% Personnel: 0

Active Fire Today, Cooler Temperatures Coming

Caribou Fire: On the east and south east side of the fire, hand crews continue to hold and improve lines as well as mop-up. Firefighters and equipment operators will build direct and indirect fireline along the north side of Marias Mountain from Young Creek west to Lime Creek. Fire progression on the southwest side of the fire has been slowed by existing timber harvest units and existing roads in the area. Heavy equipment completed the contingency fireline in the Blacktail Creek area north to the Canadian border. Helicopters and Canadian CL-415 water scoopers will be used again today to help slow fire growth. A scooper plane holds approximately 1,600 gallons of water. Yesterday, four scooper planes dropped a total of approximately 140,800 gallons of water on active fire areas.

Caribou Evacuations: All areas in West Kootenai remain in Pre-Evacuation Warning. This includes West Kootenai North and South of Tooley Lake, Spring Creek, Dodge Creek, and Basin Creek.

Caribou Fire Closures: A Closure Order remains in place for the Caribou Fire. Closure Orders and maps under the “Closures” tab on Inciweb.


Gibralter Ridge Fire: The fire continues to burn in Williams Creek. Hand crews are brushing along Grave Creek Road. Crews will remain in the area to patrol and mop-up hot spots. The fire moved two miles down the Whale Creek drainage yesterday on the Flathead National Forest (FNF). FNF fire crews wrapped the Ninko cabin and are providing structure protection.

Gibralter Ridge Evacuations: A Pre-Evacuation Warning remains in effect for the Sherman Creek, Griffith Creek, Therriault Pass Road, Stevens Creek, Glen Lake and Sinclair Creek (south/east of West Road) areas.

Gibralter Ridge Closures: Grave Creek Road and the Ten Lakes Recreation area are closed above the Grave Creek/Foothills Road junction. Closure Orders and maps under the “Closures” tab on Inciweb.

Weasel Fire: The fire is actively burning through thick Subalpine fir and is spreading northeast to Tuchuck Mountain. Timber and heavy brush are contributing to the fire spread flanking both sides of Weasel Lake. The Weasel Cabin and dock are wrapped with fire resistant material. No private property or structures are threatened.

Weather: Cooler temperatures are coming with a cold front coming from the north. Cooler air will decrease temperatures to the 60s in the mountains and relative humidity will increase to 25-30%. Winds will be erratic with the potential for gusts up to 25 mph on the ridgetops and 15 mph on the slope and valley bottom.

Resources Threatened: Private property, structures, historic resources, recreational resources, timber, terrestrial and aquatic habitats.

Fire Restrictions: Lincoln County and the Kootenai National Forest are in Stage II Fire Restrictions due to Extreme Fire Danger. For information on fire restrictions, please visit firerestrictions.us

Cause: Lightning Containment: 0% Personnel: 0

Another Red Flag Warning for Today; Fire Activity Expected to Increase

Caribou Fire: Hand crews continue to hold and improve lines as well as mop-up along the east and south east side of the fire. Firefighters and equipment operators will focus efforts on finishing fireline along the north side of Marias Mountain and from Young Creek west to Lime Creek using a combination of direct and indirect fireline along with burning operations to strengthen lines. On the west side of the fire, heavy equipment continues working on indirect line using existing roads in the Blacktail Creek area north to the Canadian border. Air support including helicopters and Canadian CL-415 water scoopers were used yesterday and if conditions allow will be used again today to help slow fire growth.

Caribou Evacuations: All areas in West Kootenai remain in Pre-Evacuation Warning. This includes West Kootenai North and South of Tooley Lake, Spring Creek, Dodge Creek, and Basin Creek.

Caribou Fire Closures: A Closure Order remains in place for the Caribou Fire. Closure Orders and maps under the “Closures” tab on Inciweb.


Gibralter Ridge Fire: The fire continues to burn in Williams Creek and has moved up and over Locke Mountain and into the head of Whale Creek on the Flathead National Forest. Hand crews are building fireline between the mouth of Williams Creek and Grave Creek Rd as well as continuing to improve Grave Creek Road. Crews will remain in the area to patrol and mop up hot spots.

Gibralter Ridge Evacuations: A Pre-Evacuation Warning remains in effect for the Sherman Creek, Griffith Creek, Therriault Pass Road, Stevens Creek, Glen Lake and Sinclair Creek (south/east of West Road) areas.

Gibralter Ridge Closures: Grave Creek Road and the Ten Lakes Recreation area are closed above the Grave Creek/Foothills Road junction. Closure Orders and maps under the “Closures” tab on Inciweb.

Weasel Fire: The fire is burning northeast through thick Subalpine fir toward Tuchuck Mountain. No private property or structures are threatened; Forest Service Weasel Cabin and dock are wrapped with fire resistant material.


Weather: Red Flag Warning issued from noon today to midnight. Hotter and dryer with southwest winds with the potential for gusts up to 25 mph on the ridgetops and 15 mph on the slope and valley bottom.

Resources Threatened: Private property, structures, historic resources, recreational resources, timber, terrestrial and aquatic habitats.

Fire Restrictions: Lincoln County and the Kootenai National Forest are in Stage II Fire Restrictions due to Extreme Fire Danger. For information on fire restrictions, please visit firerestrictions.us

entry.content:
Moose Peak and West Fork Fires Daily Fact Sheet 9.12.17

Incident: Moose Peak Fire Wildfire
Released: 10 min. ago

Fire Information Number: (406) 209-9961 Evacuation Information: (406) 293-6295

Location: West Fork is 7 miles northwest of Libby, MT Size: 14,826

Cause: Lightning Containment: 0% Personnel: 247

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5592/

Location: Moose Peak Fire originated near Moose Peak in Sanders County, MT Size: 8,834

Cause: Lightning Containment: 0% Personnel: 28

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5583/

Visit Lincoln County Webpage www.lincolncountymt.us to sign-up for the County Code Red notification system.

Weather: A Red Flag Warning is in effect from 12 pm to 12 am today. Critical fire weather conditions are expected this afternoon for warm temperatures, clear skies, critically low humidity and breezy southwest winds. A cold front will cross the area tonight bringing in cooler air and cloud cover for Wednesday. Showers are likely on Thursday.

West Fork Fire Yesterday: Fire continued to back down to the Quartz Creek Road where engine crews were patrolling and extinguishing hotspots that have crossed the road. Logging equipment was moved from the Quartz Creek Road to the Pipe Creek Road. CL-415 Super Scooper aircraft worked on the north end of the fire near Mount Tom where the fire was very active yesterday evening. The Scoopers had a 9 minute turn-around time from Lake Koocanusa to the fire.

Today’s Planned Actions: Active fire behavior is expected in all areas of the fire. The Boise Hotshot crew arrived yesterday and will split into two modules; one working in the Pipe Creek area and the other working on the Moose Peak Fire. The logging equipment will continue to work on the east side of the fire improving the roads and fireline. Logs will be decked instead of hauling them to increase line construction efficiency. Structure assessments will continue on all residences in the West Fork Fire area.

West Fork Fire Evacuations: Some evacuation orders have been lifted. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

West Fork Fire Closures: The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the West Fork Fire. The map and order is located under the closure tab on the Inciweb Page.

Moose Peak Yesterday: Growth was minimal on the west flank of the fire despite active burning until 10:30 last night. Fire continues to back slowly downhill to the east in the Fishtrap Creek area. Crews patrolled and monitored the fireline from Miller Lake to Fisher Creek. The primary containment line is almost complete on the north side of the fire from Miller Lake east to Fishtrap Road. Helicopters provided water drops to assist the firefighters in this area to slow the fire’s growth to the north.

Today’s Planned Actions: The north containment line should be completed today and division supervisors will scout areas where a containment line may be constructed closer to the active fire. The fire will want to move to the north and east with the wind conditions today. Crews will be prepared to hold the established firelines where it is safe to do so. Helicopter will continue to assist ground crews as visibility allows.

Moose Peak Fire Pre - Evacuations: Evacuation notices have been issued for East Fisher Rd and Bayhorse Ranch. Pre-Evacuation notices have been issued for McGinnis Meadows. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

Moose Peak Fire Closures: Sylvan Lake campground has been closed as well as. The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the Moose Peak Fire. The map and order is located under the closure tab on the Inciweb Page.

###

entry.content:
Fire Update 9-11-17

Incident: Weasel Wildfire
Released: 39 min. ago

Related Information

  • fire update 9-11-17 (pdf 135 kb)
  • Map 9-11-17 (pdf 568 kb)

Fire Information Line: 406-272-2082

Location: Caribou Fire located 21 miles northwest of Eureka, MT Current Size: 22,388 Total Acres

Cause: Lightning Containment: 25% Personnel: 385 United States: 19,880 Canada: 2,508

Email: CaribouFire2017@gmail.com Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5539/

Location: Gibralter Ridge Fire located seven miles east of Eureka, MT Current Size: 8,932 Acres

Cause: Lightning Containment: 27% Personnel: 65

Email: GibralterRidgeFire2017@gmail.com Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5474/

Location: Weasel Fire located 17 miles northeast of Eureka, MT Current Size: 869 Acres

Cause: Lightning Containment: 0% Personnel: 0

Gibralter Ridge Fire Pushes South and East, Red Flag Warning Today

Caribou Fire: Yesterday, firefighters focused on the south and southwest side of the fire continuing fireline construction and engaging direct attack when possible near Lime Creek. Heavy equipment and crews continued building fireline along the north side of Marias Mountain into the South Fork of Young Creek and Blacktail Creek area.

Today, Firefighters and equipment operators will continue building fireline along the north side of Marias Mountain and from Young Creek west towards Lime Creek. On the west side of the fire, heavy equipment is working on indirect line using existing roads in the Blacktail Creek area to the Canadian border.

Caribou Evacuations: All areas in West Kootenai remain in Pre-Evacuation Warning. This includes West Kootenai North and South of Tooley Lake, Spring Creek, Dodge Creek, and Basin Creek.

Caribou Fire Closures: A Closure Order remains in place for the Caribou Fire. Closure Orders and maps under the “Closures” tab on Inciweb.


Gibralter Ridge Fire: The fire progressed south along Williams Creek toward Locke, Mountain. Fire managers will evaluate fire activity in the area and use helicopters or aircraft to check fire growth. Crews continue prepping Grave Creek Road and will remain in the area to patrol and mop up hot spots.

Gibralter Ridge Evacuations: A Pre-Evacuation Warning remains in effect for the Sherman Creek, Griffith Creek, Therriault Pass Road, Stevens Creek, Glen Lake and Sinclair Creek (south/east of West Road) areas.

Gibralter Ridge Closures: Grave Creek Road and the Ten Lakes Recreation area are closed above the Grave Creek/Foothills Road junction. Closure Orders and maps under the “Closures” tab on Inciweb.

Weasel Fire: Fire managers were able to view the fire yesterday and will continue evaluating staffing needs. The fire is burning northeast through thick Subalpine fir toward Tuchuck Mountain. No private property or structures are threatened; Forest Service Weasel Cabin and dock had been wrapped ahead of yesterday’s fire spread.


Weather: Critical fire weather day. Red Flag Warning issued from noon today to midnight. Hotter and dryer with southwest winds with the potential for gusts up to 20-30 mph on the ridgetops.

Resources Threatened: Private property, structures, historic resources, recreational resources, timber, terrestrial and aquatic habitats.

Fire Restrictions: Lincoln County and the Kootenai National Forest are in Stage II Fire Restrictions due to Extreme Fire Danger. For information on fire restrictions, please visit firerestrictions.us

A Red Flag Warning in effect for this afternoon as the temperature will reach into the 80s and...
entry.content:
Moose Peak and West Fork Fires Daily Fact Sheet 09.11.17

Incident: Moose Peak Fire Wildfire
Released: 30 min. ago

Related Information

  • Moose Peak and West Fork Fires Fact Sheet 9.11.17 (pdf 282 kb)

Fire Information Number: (406) 209-9961 Evacuation Information: (406) 293-6295

Location: West Fork is 7 miles northwest of Libby, MT Size: 13,372

Cause: Lightning Containment: 0% Personnel: 235

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5592/

Location: Moose Peak Fire originated near Moose Peak in Sanders County, MT Size: 8,209

Cause: Lightning Containment: 0% Personnel: 26

Email: WestForkMoosePeakFires@gmail.com InciWeb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5583/

Visit Lincoln County Webpage www.lincolncountymt.us to sign-up for the County Code Red system.

·Community Meeting at 6:00 p.m. at Thompson Lake Christian Retreat, 593 ACM Road South ·

Weather: Although cloud cover shortened the active burning period on both fires yesterday, fire intensity was the highest that it has been for several days and is expected to continue today. A Red Flag Warning in effect for this afternoon as the temperature will reach into the 80s and relative humidity will range 13-18%. Winds are forecasted to be from the southwest at 5-10 mph with gusts to 20 mph but can push fire to the northeast if aligned with the terrain. South facing aspects will be especially active as the day gets hotter and drier. Tuesday is expected to be a near critical weather day with high winds and low relative humidity.

West Fork Fire Yesterday: Conditions allowed for crews to burnout along the USFS 6144 Road to the Quartz Creek road ahead of the fire which was backing slowly down the west side to the Quartz Creek Road. In some places burning debris rolled across the road but crews were able to contain all the spots on the west side of Quartz Creek road.

Fire activity increased through the day near Mount Tom and the DC-10 air tanker was used to drop retardant just north of Mount Tom. This retardant line helped to slow fire growth and allow equipment and crews time to improve the primary containment lines near the junction of 17 Mile Road and Pipe Creek Road. Four helicopters dropped water in the USFS 4613 road area as fire pushed to the east. A spot fire was detected by the Air Attack Group Supervisor near Gold Hill approximately six miles due east of Loon Lake. Two heavy air tankers were able to box the spot fire in with retardant. The east side of the Bobtail Ridge burnout was completed today. The last section was tied into a dozer line at the north end of Bobtail Road.

Today’s Planned Actions: Crews will slowly burn north along the USFS 6144 Road as conditions allow. Engines will patrol and monitor the fire as it backs down Quartz Creek Road. Equipment and operators will be improving old logging roads and dozer lines on the north and east sides of the fire, creating a fireline. The dozer line from the Bobtail Road to Pipe Creek will be improved as a containment line. Aerial resources will be utilized as needed and if conditions allow.

West Fork Fire Evacuations: Some evacuation orders have been lifted. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

West Fork Fire Closures: The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the West Fork Fire. The map and order is located under the closure tab on the Inciweb Page.

Moose Peak Yesterday: As fire became more active in the Miller Lake area, crews burned out a section of unburned fuel along the dozer line extending north of the lake. A masticator began working east of Miller Lake along the primary containment line. Aerial resources quickly responded to a spotfire outside of the primary containment line east of Fishtrap Creek.

Today’s Planned Actions Firefighters will monitor yesterday’s burnout west of Miller Lake. The heavy equipment will continue to work on improving the primary containment lines south of McGinnis Meadows from Fishtrap Creek. The aerial resources will be available again today to assist as fire behavior increases.

Fire Behavior: Fire will remain very active today and a Red Flag Warning is in effect this afternoon. SW winds could push fire to the northeast, especially where winds are aligned with Vermillion Creek.

Moose Peak Fire Pre - Evacuations: Evacuation notices have been issued for East Fisher Rd and Bayhorse Ranch. Pre-Evacuation notices have been issued for McGinnis Meadows. Please check the Lincoln County Sheriff’s Facebook page or call (406) 293-6295 for the most up-to-date information on evacuations.

Moose Peak Fire Closures: Sylvan Lake campground has been closed as well as. The Kootenai National Forest has issued a closure order in effect for the Moose Peak Fire. The map and order is located under the closure tab on the Inciweb Page.

###
